Top-3 Similar Questions: ul_131089: Fetching all Git repositories in the background
so_19337405: How to fetch certain filenames using grep?
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_131089: savelog -n -c 400 ~/log/git-fetch.log
find ~/git -type d -execdir [ -d '{}/.git' ]  \; -print -prune |
    parallel --gnu --keep-order \
    "date; echo {}; cd {}; git fetch --all --verbose" \
    >> ~/log/git-fetch.log 2>&1

Explanations about Options.-iname:
Like -name, but the match is case insensitive. For example, the patterns `fo*' and
 `F??' match the file names `Foo', `FOO', `foo', `fOo', etc. The pattern `*foo*`
 will also match a file called '.foobar'.

Explanations about Options.--git-dir:
Set the path to the repository. This can also be controlled by setting the GIT_DIR
 environment variable. It can be an absolute path or relative path to current working
 directory.

Top-3 Similar Questions: so_58772067: Why doesn't the GitHub API return all branches for a repository?
Top-3 Scripts:
so_58772067: curl -Lv 'http://api.github.com/repos/bminor/glibc/branches?per_page=100'

$ curl -sL 'http://api.github.com/repos/bminor/glibc/branches?page=2&per_page=100' \
      | jq -r '.[] | select(.name | contains("release")).name'
hjl/release/2.20/master
hjl/x32/release/2.12
hjl/x32/release/2.15

Explanations about Options.-s:
Silent or quiet mode. Don't show progress meter or error messages. Makes Curl
 mute. It will still output the data you ask for, potentially even to the
 terminal/stdout unless you redirect it.
